1. Budget Constraint
• Suppose there is a consumer whose name is Pepe. He is the representative agent of all customers in our 
society.

1. Budget Constraint
• We want to capture that consumers have a limited amount of income to spend on the things they need and 
want.
• Pepe has 5,600 wons in spending money each week.
• He can allocate this spending between meal ticket and shirts. 
• The meal tickets cost 700 wons each, and the shirts are 1,400 wons each.

1. Budget Constraint
• Of course, the budget constraint diagram containing just two goods is not realistic. 
• Because, in a modern economy, people choose from thousands of goods.
• However, thinking about a model with many goods can be just a straightforward extension of what we 
discussed here.
• The point is that there is always a trade-off problem in decisions.

1. Budget Constraint
• Economists call it opportunity cost.
• Opportunity cost indicate what have to be given up to obtain something. In other words, opportunity cost 
is the value of the next best alternative.
• For Pepe, the opportunity cost of 1 shirt is the 2 meal tickets. 
• He would decide to buy one more shirt, If the value of the extra shirt exceed the value of the alternative 
(2 meal tickets).
1. Budget Constraint
• A fundamental principle of economics is that every choice has an opportunity cost.
• If you sleep through your economics class, the opportunity cost might be the time which would be spent 
to make up the class.
• If you choose to marry one person, you give up the opportunity to marry anyone else. 
• In short, opportunity cost is all around us and part of human existence.
1. Budget Constraint
• In many cases, it is reasonable to refer to the opportunity cost as the price.
• For example, attending graduate school is the case where the opportunity cost exceeds the monetary cost. 
The explicit costs of attending college might be about tuition, books, room and board, and other expenses. 
But in addition, during the hours that you are attending class and studying, it is impossible to work at a 
paying job. Thus, graduate school imposes both an out-of-pocket cost and an opportunity cost of lost 
earnings.

2. Utility
• People desire goods and services for the satisfaction or utility from using those goods and services.
• Utility is the term which economists use to describe a person’s level of satisfaction/usefulness or 
happiness with his or her choices.
• Of course, in our daily life, we don’t measure such a thing. But, in model, it can be a quite useful 
instrument to replicate the underlying incentive structure of each individuals.
2. Utility
Economists assume the feature of utility
1.The more of some good one consumes, the more utility 
one obtains.
2. As a person consumes more of a good, the additional (or 
marginal) utility from each additional unit of the good 
declines.
2. Utility
• It is a general pattern that consumption of the first few units of good tends to bring a higher level of 
utility than consumption of later units.
• Suppose that you are in thirsty. You can compare the degree to which the first few drops of water relieve 
the thirst and the extent to which the drinking water later resolves the thirst.
• Economists refer to this pattern as the law of diminishing marginal utility.
• It means that, the utility of a person receives from consuming the first unit of a good is typically more 
than the utility received from consuming the fifth or the tenth unit of that same good.
2. Utility
• The law of diminishing marginal utility explains why people and societies rarely make all-or-nothing 
choices. 
• Most of people would not say, “My favorite food is potato, so I will eat nothing but only potatoes from 
now on.”
• Even if you get a very high level of utility from your favorite food, if you ate it exclusively, the marginal 
utility from those last few servings would not be very high.

Producer’s optimization problem
◦ Business sector or firms combines inputs of labor, capital, land, and raw or 
finished component materials to produce outputs.
◦ This activity of production includes not only manufacturing but also any 
process or service that creates value, including transportation, distribution, 
wholesale and retail sales.
◦ The objective of business : profit
Producer’s optimization problem
◦ Profit = Revenue – cost
◦ Revenue = Price × Quantity
◦ Cost = the amount that the firm pays to make and sell their products is called total cost. 
◦ The cost structure of firms can be broken down into some 
common underlying patterns. In the short run, we can classify the 
costs into fixed costs and variable costs.
◦ Fixed costs are the costs that cannot be changed in the short run.
◦ Variable costs are the costs that can be changed.
The structure of production cost
◦ Fixed costs are expenditures that do not change regardless of the level of 
production, at least not in the short term.
◦ For example, the cost of building factory or buying heavy equipment, research and 
development costs, advertising expenses. 
◦ The level of fixed costs varies according to the feature of the products or 
industry. 
◦ For instance, manufacturing mobile phone or computer chips requires an 
expensive factory. But, a food-truck or a painting artist can get by with 
relatively less fixed costs.
The structure of production cost
◦ Variable costs are incurred in the act of producing.
◦ For example, wages and cost to buy intermediate goods are variable costs.
◦ The more you produce, the greater the variable cost.
◦ Total cost = fixed cost + variable cost.
The nature of production
◦ Two assumptions:
1. Positivity (with respect to input)
2. Law of diminishing marginal production
◦ Marginal product of any input : the additional quantity of output obtained 
from one additional unit of that input.
Example : Pepe’s chicken house
◦ Assume that the fixed costs of operating the chicken house, including the space and 
equipment, are 100.
◦ The variable costs are the costs of hiring worker, which in our example is 50 per deliver. 
◦ Variable cost :  price of input  x  quantity of input.
◦ When one unit of the input (worker) is added, the cost would be increased as much as the 
price of the input (50 for the wage).

Some chicken houses can not sell their chickens. So, Raw chickens, oils, flours 
at their storages starts to go bad.
Some chicken houses will want to cut prices, because it is better to sell at a 
lower price than not to sell at all. 
So, if the price is above the equilibrium level, incentives built into the structure 
of demand and supply pressures for the price to fall toward the equilibrium.

4. Equilibrium
The word “equilibrium” means “balance.” 
If a market is at its equilibrium price and quantity, then it has no reason to 
move away from that point. 
However, if a market is not at equilibrium, then economic pressures arise to 
move the market toward the equilibrium price and the equilibrium quantity.
4. Equilibrium
In 1890, the famous economist Alfred Marshall wrote that asking whether 
supply or demand determined a price was like arguing
“whether it is the upper or the 
under blade of a pair of 
scissors that cuts a piece of 
paper.” 

5. Shift of demand curve
Price, however, is not the only thing that influences demand and supply.
What if overall consumer’s income has changed? 
Sometime preferences can be suddenly changed.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected?

5. Shift of demand curve
Does the higher income always bring greater demand?
A product whose demand rises when income rises is called a normal good.
but, there is a few exceptions to this pattern do exist. 
A product whose demand falls when income rises is called an inferior good. 
5. Shift of demand curve
And, for some goods such as luxury cars, fine cuisines, or jewelry, the effect of 
a rise in income can be especially pronounced.
We called those luxury goods.
A luxury good is a good for which demand increases more than proportionally 
as income rises, 
5. Shift of demand curve
Of course, income is not the only factor that causes a shift in demand.
We can think about some of other factors that shift demand curves.
One of those is changing tastes or preferences.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
It might cause a severe avoiding to eat chickens.
5. Shift of demand curve
Demographic changes can also be a important factor.
Actually, the demographic changes is combined with the changes in preference.
Since the consumption preference of youth and old person is quite different, 
changes in the demographic structure directly affects the overall preference of 
the society.
5. Shift of demand curve
Another example is the housing demand.
Since the demand for owning houses is usually peaked in the middle age about 
40s, the overall housing demand can also be peaked, when the number of 
middle-aged in the country is the highest level.
Some economists have tried to predict the future housing prices by using 
predictable demographic changes.
Mankiw, N. G., & Weil, D. N. (1989). The baby boom, the baby bust, and the 
housing market. Regional science and urban economics, 19(2), 235-258.
5. Shift of demand curve
It is also true that expectations about the future price (or expectations about 
tastes and preferences, income, and so on) can affect demand.
For example, if people hear that a hurricane is coming, they may rush to the 
store to buy flashlight batteries and bottled water. 
These changes can push the demand curve to the right.
5. Shift of demand curve
One interest thing is that some goods can be seriously affected by the 
expectation.
For example, we can think about housing market.
Demand for housing is not only determined  by preferences, but also by the 
expectations for capital gain.
This feature of housing markets sometimes causes speculations in housing 
markets.
6. Shift of supply curve
How about the supply curves? 
One of most important factor affecting the supply curve might be the 
production cost.
If a firm faces lower costs of production, a firm’s profits go up. This can be 
shown by the supply curve shifting to the right.
if a firm faces higher costs of production, then it will earn lower profits at any 
given selling price for its products. In this case, the supply curve shifts to the 
left.

Several other things affect the cost of production, too. 
We can think about new technologies for production, and some government 
policies.
6. Shift of supply curve
When producers develops or discovers a technology that allows the firm to 
produce at a lower cost, the supply curve will shift to the right, as well. 
Think about the cost of raising a chicken in chicken farm and the poultry 
factory system.

6. Shift of supply curve
Government policies also can affect the cost of production and the supply 
curve through taxes, regulations, and subsidies.
A subsidy occurs when the government pays a firm directly or reduces the 
firm’s taxes if the firm carries out certain actions. 
From the firm’s perspective, taxes or regulations are an additional cost of 
production that shifts supply to the left, leading the firm to produce a lower 
quantity at every given price. 
So, government subsidies reduce the cost of production and increase supply at 
every given price, shifting supply to the right.
7. Price controls
In some cases, discontent over prices turns into public pressure on politicians

7. Price controls
Laws that government enacts to regulate prices are called Price controls.
Price controls come in two ways.
A price ceiling keeps a price from rising above a certain level.
And, a price floor keeps a price from falling below a certain level.

2. Utility
• It is a general pattern that consumption of the first few units of good tends to bring a higher level of 
utility than consumption of later units.
• Suppose that you are in thirsty. You can compare the degree to which the first few drops of water relieve 
the thirst and the extent to which the drinking water later resolves the thirst.
• Economists refer to this pattern as the law of diminishing marginal utility.
• It means that, the utility of a person receives from consuming the first unit of a good is typically more 
than the utility received from consuming the fifth or the tenth unit of that same good.
2. Utility
• The law of diminishing marginal utility explains why people and societies rarely make all-or-nothing 
choices.

now on.”
• Even if you get a very high level of utility from your favorite food, if you ate it exclusively, the marginal 
utility from those last few servings would not be very high.

Producer’s optimization problem
◦ Business sector or firms combines inputs of labor, capital, land, and raw or 
finished component materials to produce outputs.
◦ This activity of production includes not only manufacturing but also any 
process or service that creates value, including transportation, distribution, 
wholesale and retail sales.
◦ The objective of business : profit
Producer’s optimization problem
◦ Profit = Revenue – cost
◦ Revenue = Price × Quantity
◦ Cost = the amount that the firm pays to make and sell their products is called total cost. 
◦ The cost structure of firms can be broken down into some 
common underlying patterns. In the short run, we can classify the 
costs into fixed costs and variable costs.
◦ Fixed costs are the costs that cannot be changed in the short run.
◦ Variable costs are the costs that can be changed.
The structure of production cost
◦ Fixed costs are expenditures that do not change regardless of the level of 
production, at least not in the short term.
◦ For example, the cost of building factory or buying heavy equipment, research and 
development costs, advertising expenses. 
◦ The level of fixed costs varies according to the feature of the products or 
industry. 
◦ For instance, manufacturing mobile phone or computer chips requires an 
expensive factory. But, a food-truck or a painting artist can get by with 
relatively less fixed costs.
The structure of production cost
◦ Variable costs are incurred in the act of producing.
◦ For example, wages and cost to buy intermediate goods are variable costs.
◦ The more you produce, the greater the variable cost.
◦ Total cost = fixed cost + variable cost.
The nature of production
◦ Two assumptions:
1. Positivity (with respect to input)
2. Law of diminishing marginal production
◦ Marginal product of any input : the additional quantity of output obtained 
from one additional unit of that input.

The total number of units purchased at that price is called the quantity

demanded at those prices.

Demand curves can somewhat different for each product. 
They may appear relatively steep or flat, or they may be straight or curved. 
Nearly all demand curves share the fundamental similarity that they slope 
down from left to right. 
2. Supply curve
Quantity supplied means the amount of some good or service a producer is 
willing to supply at each price. 
Price is what the producer receives for selling one unit of a good or service. 
A rise in price almost always leads to an increase in the quantity supplied of

4. Equilibrium
The word “equilibrium” means “balance.” 
If a market is at its equilibrium price and quantity, then it has no reason to 
move away from that point. 
However, if a market is not at equilibrium, then economic pressures arise to 
move the market toward the equilibrium price and the equilibrium quantity.
4. Equilibrium
In 1890, the famous economist Alfred Marshall wrote that asking whether 
supply or demand determined a price was like arguing
“whether it is the upper or the 
under blade of a pair of 
scissors that cuts a piece of 
paper.” 

5. Shift of demand curve
Price, however, is not the only thing that influences demand and supply.
What if overall consumer’s income has changed? 
Sometime preferences can be suddenly changed.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected?

5. Shift of demand curve
Does the higher income always bring greater demand?
A product whose demand rises when income rises is called a normal good.
but, there is a few exceptions to this pattern do exist. 
A product whose demand falls when income rises is called an inferior good. 
5. Shift of demand curve
And, for some goods such as luxury cars, fine cuisines, or jewelry, the effect of 
a rise in income can be especially pronounced.
We called those luxury goods.
A luxury good is a good for which demand increases more than proportionally 
as income rises, 
5. Shift of demand curve
Of course, income is not the only factor that causes a shift in demand.
We can think about some of other factors that shift demand curves.
One of those is changing tastes or preferences.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
It might cause a severe avoiding to eat chickens.
5. Shift of demand curve
Demographic changes can also be a important factor.
Actually, the demographic changes is combined with the changes in preference.
Since the consumption preference of youth and old person is quite different, 
changes in the demographic structure directly affects the overall preference of 
the society.
5. Shift of demand curve
Another example is the housing demand.
Since the demand for owning houses is usually peaked in the middle age about 
40s, the overall housing demand can also be peaked, when the number of 
middle-aged in the country is the highest level.
Some economists have tried to predict the future housing prices by using 
predictable demographic changes.
Mankiw, N. G., & Weil, D. N. (1989). The baby boom, the baby bust, and the 
housing market. Regional science and urban economics, 19(2), 235-258.
5. Shift of demand curve
It is also true that expectations about the future price (or expectations about 
tastes and preferences, income, and so on) can affect demand.
For example, if people hear that a hurricane is coming, they may rush to the 
store to buy flashlight batteries and bottled water. 
These changes can push the demand curve to the right.
5. Shift of demand curve
One interest thing is that some goods can be seriously affected by the 
expectation.
For example, we can think about housing market.
Demand for housing is not only determined  by preferences, but also by the 
expectations for capital gain.
This feature of housing markets sometimes causes speculations in housing 
markets.
6. Shift of supply curve
How about the supply curves? 
One of most important factor affecting the supply curve might be the 
production cost.
If a firm faces lower costs of production, a firm’s profits go up. This can be 
shown by the supply curve shifting to the right.
if a firm faces higher costs of production, then it will earn lower profits at any 
given selling price for its products. In this case, the supply curve shifts to the 
left.

We can think about new technologies for production, and some government

When producers develops or discovers a technology that allows the firm to 
produce at a lower cost, the supply curve will shift to the right, as well. 
Think about the cost of raising a chicken in chicken farm and the poultry

6. Shift of supply curve
Government policies also can affect the cost of production and the supply 
curve through taxes, regulations, and subsidies.
A subsidy occurs when the government pays a firm directly or reduces the 
firm’s taxes if the firm carries out certain actions. 
From the firm’s perspective, taxes or regulations are an additional cost of 
production that shifts supply to the left, leading the firm to produce a lower 
quantity at every given price. 
So, government subsidies reduce the cost of production and increase supply at 
every given price, shifting supply to the right.

Producer’s optimization problem
◦ Business sector or firms combines inputs of labor, capital, land, and raw or 
finished component materials to produce outputs.
◦ This activity of production includes not only manufacturing but also any 
process or service that creates value, including transportation, distribution, 
wholesale and retail sales.

Producer’s optimization problem
◦ Profit = Revenue – cost
◦ Revenue = Price × Quantity
◦ Cost = the amount that the firm pays to make and sell their products is called total cost. 
◦ The cost structure of firms can be broken down into some 
common underlying patterns. In the short run, we can classify the 
costs into fixed costs and variable costs.
◦ Fixed costs are the costs that cannot be changed in the short run.
◦ Variable costs are the costs that can be changed.
The structure of production cost
◦ Fixed costs are expenditures that do not change regardless of the level of 
production, at least not in the short term.
◦ For example, the cost of building factory or buying heavy equipment, research and 
development costs, advertising expenses. 
◦ The level of fixed costs varies according to the feature of the products or 
industry. 
◦ For instance, manufacturing mobile phone or computer chips requires an 
expensive factory. But, a food-truck or a painting artist can get by with 
relatively less fixed costs.
The structure of production cost
◦ Variable costs are incurred in the act of producing.
◦ For example, wages and cost to buy intermediate goods are variable costs.
◦ The more you produce, the greater the variable cost.
◦ Total cost = fixed cost + variable cost.
The nature of production

1. Positivity (with respect to input)
2. Law of diminishing marginal production

5. Shift of demand curve
Price, however, is not the only thing that influences demand and supply.
What if overall consumer’s income has changed? 
Sometime preferences can be suddenly changed.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
5. Shift of demand curve

5. Shift of demand curve
Does the higher income always bring greater demand?
A product whose demand rises when income rises is called a normal good.
but, there is a few exceptions to this pattern do exist. 
A product whose demand falls when income rises is called an inferior good. 
5. Shift of demand curve
And, for some goods such as luxury cars, fine cuisines, or jewelry, the effect of 
a rise in income can be especially pronounced.
We called those luxury goods.
A luxury good is a good for which demand increases more than proportionally 
as income rises, 
5. Shift of demand curve
Of course, income is not the only factor that causes a shift in demand.
We can think about some of other factors that shift demand curves.
One of those is changing tastes or preferences.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
It might cause a severe avoiding to eat chickens.
5. Shift of demand curve
Demographic changes can also be a important factor.
Actually, the demographic changes is combined with the changes in preference.
Since the consumption preference of youth and old person is quite different, 
changes in the demographic structure directly affects the overall preference of 
the society.
5. Shift of demand curve
Another example is the housing demand.
Since the demand for owning houses is usually peaked in the middle age about 
40s, the overall housing demand can also be peaked, when the number of 
middle-aged in the country is the highest level.
Some economists have tried to predict the future housing prices by using 
predictable demographic changes.
Mankiw, N. G., & Weil, D. N. (1989). The baby boom, the baby bust, and the 
housing market. Regional science and urban economics, 19(2), 235-258.
5. Shift of demand curve
It is also true that expectations about the future price (or expectations about 
tastes and preferences, income, and so on) can affect demand.
For example, if people hear that a hurricane is coming, they may rush to the 
store to buy flashlight batteries and bottled water. 
These changes can push the demand curve to the right.
5. Shift of demand curve
One interest thing is that some goods can be seriously affected by the 
expectation.
For example, we can think about housing market.
Demand for housing is not only determined  by preferences, but also by the 
expectations for capital gain.
This feature of housing markets sometimes causes speculations in housing 
markets.
6. Shift of supply curve
How about the supply curves? 
One of most important factor affecting the supply curve might be the 
production cost.
If a firm faces lower costs of production, a firm’s profits go up. This can be 
shown by the supply curve shifting to the right.
if a firm faces higher costs of production, then it will earn lower profits at any 
given selling price for its products. In this case, the supply curve shifts to the 
left.
6. Shift of supply curve

6. Shift of supply curve
Several other things affect the cost of production, too. 
We can think about new technologies for production, and some government 
policies.
6. Shift of supply curve
When producers develops or discovers a technology that allows the firm to 
produce at a lower cost, the supply curve will shift to the right, as well. 
Think about the cost of raising a chicken in chicken farm and the poultry 
factory system.
6. Shift of supply curve
Government policies also can affect the cost of production and the supply 
curve through taxes, regulations, and subsidies.
A subsidy occurs when the government pays a firm directly or reduces the 
firm’s taxes if the firm carries out certain actions. 
From the firm’s perspective, taxes or regulations are an additional cost of 
production that shifts supply to the left, leading the firm to produce a lower 
quantity at every given price. 
So, government subsidies reduce the cost of production and increase supply at 
every given price, shifting supply to the right.

1. Budget Constraint
• A fundamental principle of economics is that every choice has an opportunity cost.
• If you sleep through your economics class, the opportunity cost might be the time which would be spent 
to make up the class.
• If you choose to marry one person, you give up the opportunity to marry anyone else. 
• In short, opportunity cost is all around us and part of human existence.
1. Budget Constraint
• In many cases, it is reasonable to refer to the opportunity cost as the price.
• For example, attending graduate school is the case where the opportunity cost exceeds the monetary cost. 
The explicit costs of attending college might be about tuition, books, room and board, and other expenses. 
But in addition, during the hours that you are attending class and studying, it is impossible to work at a 
paying job. Thus, graduate school imposes both an out-of-pocket cost and an opportunity cost of lost 
earnings.

• People desire goods and services for the satisfaction or utility from using those goods and services.
• Utility is the term which economists use to describe a person’s level of satisfaction/usefulness or 
happiness with his or her choices.
• Of course, in our daily life, we don’t measure such a thing. But, in model, it can be a quite useful 
instrument to replicate the underlying incentive structure of each individuals.
2. Utility
Economists assume the feature of utility
1.The more of some good one consumes, the more utility 
one obtains.
2. As a person consumes more of a good, the additional (or 
marginal) utility from each additional unit of the good 
declines.
2. Utility
• It is a general pattern that consumption of the first few units of good tends to bring a higher level of 
utility than consumption of later units.
• Suppose that you are in thirsty. You can compare the degree to which the first few drops of water relieve 
the thirst and the extent to which the drinking water later resolves the thirst.
• Economists refer to this pattern as the law of diminishing marginal utility.
• It means that, the utility of a person receives from consuming the first unit of a good is typically more 
than the utility received from consuming the fifth or the tenth unit of that same good.
2. Utility
• The law of diminishing marginal utility explains why people and societies rarely make all-or-nothing 
choices. 
• Most of people would not say, “My favorite food is potato, so I will eat nothing but only potatoes from 
now on.”
• Even if you get a very high level of utility from your favorite food, if you ate it exclusively, the marginal 
utility from those last few servings would not be very high.

Producer’s optimization problem
◦ Business sector or firms combines inputs of labor, capital, land, and raw or 
finished component materials to produce outputs.
◦ This activity of production includes not only manufacturing but also any 
process or service that creates value, including transportation, distribution, 
wholesale and retail sales.
◦ The objective of business : profit
Producer’s optimization problem
◦ Profit = Revenue – cost
◦ Revenue = Price × Quantity
◦ Cost = the amount that the firm pays to make and sell their products is called total cost. 
◦ The cost structure of firms can be broken down into some 
common underlying patterns. In the short run, we can classify the 
costs into fixed costs and variable costs.
◦ Fixed costs are the costs that cannot be changed in the short run.
◦ Variable costs are the costs that can be changed.
The structure of production cost
◦ Fixed costs are expenditures that do not change regardless of the level of 
production, at least not in the short term.
◦ For example, the cost of building factory or buying heavy equipment, research and 
development costs, advertising expenses. 
◦ The level of fixed costs varies according to the feature of the products or 
industry. 
◦ For instance, manufacturing mobile phone or computer chips requires an 
expensive factory. But, a food-truck or a painting artist can get by with 
relatively less fixed costs.
The structure of production cost
◦ Variable costs are incurred in the act of producing.
◦ For example, wages and cost to buy intermediate goods are variable costs.
◦ The more you produce, the greater the variable cost.
◦ Total cost = fixed cost + variable cost.
The nature of production
◦ Two assumptions:
1. Positivity (with respect to input)
2. Law of diminishing marginal production
◦ Marginal product of any input : the additional quantity of output obtained 
from one additional unit of that input.

equipment, are 100.

◦ Variable cost :  price of input  x  quantity of input.
◦ When one unit of the input (worker) is added, the cost would be increased as much as the 
price of the input (50 for the wage).

Price, however, is not the only thing that influences demand and supply.

5. Shift of demand curve
Does the higher income always bring greater demand?
A product whose demand rises when income rises is called a normal good.
but, there is a few exceptions to this pattern do exist. 
A product whose demand falls when income rises is called an inferior good. 
5. Shift of demand curve
And, for some goods such as luxury cars, fine cuisines, or jewelry, the effect of 
a rise in income can be especially pronounced.
We called those luxury goods.
A luxury good is a good for which demand increases more than proportionally 
as income rises, 
5. Shift of demand curve
Of course, income is not the only factor that causes a shift in demand.
We can think about some of other factors that shift demand curves.
One of those is changing tastes or preferences.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
It might cause a severe avoiding to eat chickens.
5. Shift of demand curve
Demographic changes can also be a important factor.
Actually, the demographic changes is combined with the changes in preference.
Since the consumption preference of youth and old person is quite different, 
changes in the demographic structure directly affects the overall preference of 
the society.
5. Shift of demand curve
Another example is the housing demand.
Since the demand for owning houses is usually peaked in the middle age about 
40s, the overall housing demand can also be peaked, when the number of 
middle-aged in the country is the highest level.
Some economists have tried to predict the future housing prices by using 
predictable demographic changes.
Mankiw, N. G., & Weil, D. N. (1989). The baby boom, the baby bust, and the 
housing market. Regional science and urban economics, 19(2), 235-258.
5. Shift of demand curve
It is also true that expectations about the future price (or expectations about 
tastes and preferences, income, and so on) can affect demand.
For example, if people hear that a hurricane is coming, they may rush to the 
store to buy flashlight batteries and bottled water. 
These changes can push the demand curve to the right.
5. Shift of demand curve
One interest thing is that some goods can be seriously affected by the 
expectation.
For example, we can think about housing market.
Demand for housing is not only determined  by preferences, but also by the 
expectations for capital gain.
This feature of housing markets sometimes causes speculations in housing 
markets.
6. Shift of supply curve
How about the supply curves? 
One of most important factor affecting the supply curve might be the 
production cost.
If a firm faces lower costs of production, a firm’s profits go up. This can be 
shown by the supply curve shifting to the right.
if a firm faces higher costs of production, then it will earn lower profits at any 
given selling price for its products. In this case, the supply curve shifts to the 
left.

6. Shift of supply curve
Several other things affect the cost of production, too. 
We can think about new technologies for production, and some government 
policies.
6. Shift of supply curve
When producers develops or discovers a technology that allows the firm to 
produce at a lower cost, the supply curve will shift to the right, as well. 
Think about the cost of raising a chicken in chicken farm and the poultry 
factory system.
6. Shift of supply curve
Government policies also can affect the cost of production and the supply 
curve through taxes, regulations, and subsidies.
A subsidy occurs when the government pays a firm directly or reduces the 
firm’s taxes if the firm carries out certain actions. 
From the firm’s perspective, taxes or regulations are an additional cost of 
production that shifts supply to the left, leading the firm to produce a lower 
quantity at every given price. 
So, government subsidies reduce the cost of production and increase supply at 
every given price, shifting supply to the right.

Producer’s optimization problem
◦ Business sector or firms combines inputs of labor, capital, land, and raw or 
finished component materials to produce outputs.
◦ This activity of production includes not only manufacturing but also any 
process or service that creates value, including transportation, distribution, 
wholesale and retail sales.
◦ The objective of business : profit
Producer’s optimization problem
◦ Profit = Revenue – cost
◦ Revenue = Price × Quantity
◦ Cost = the amount that the firm pays to make and sell their products is called total cost. 
◦ The cost structure of firms can be broken down into some 
common underlying patterns. In the short run, we can classify the 
costs into fixed costs and variable costs.
◦ Fixed costs are the costs that cannot be changed in the short run.
◦ Variable costs are the costs that can be changed.
The structure of production cost
◦ Fixed costs are expenditures that do not change regardless of the level of 
production, at least not in the short term.
◦ For example, the cost of building factory or buying heavy equipment, research and 
development costs, advertising expenses. 
◦ The level of fixed costs varies according to the feature of the products or 
industry. 
◦ For instance, manufacturing mobile phone or computer chips requires an 
expensive factory. But, a food-truck or a painting artist can get by with 
relatively less fixed costs.
The structure of production cost
◦ Variable costs are incurred in the act of producing.
◦ For example, wages and cost to buy intermediate goods are variable costs.
◦ The more you produce, the greater the variable cost.
◦ Total cost = fixed cost + variable cost.
The nature of production
◦ Two assumptions:
1. Positivity (with respect to input)
2. Law of diminishing marginal production
◦ Marginal product of any input : the additional quantity of output obtained 
from one additional unit of that input.
Example : Pepe’s chicken house
◦ Assume that the fixed costs of operating the chicken house, including the space and 
equipment, are 100.

◦ Variable cost :  price of input  x  quantity of input.
◦ When one unit of the input (worker) is added, the cost would be increased as much as the 
price of the input (50 for the wage).

Demand the amount of some good or service consumers are willing and able 
to purchase at each price. 
Demand for each good and services can be obtained by individual consumer’s

Demand represent the amount of wiliness to pay of the society. 
1. Demand curve
The total number of units purchased at that price is called the quantity 
demanded. 
So, In economic terminology, demand is not the same as quantity demanded. 
Demand is mean the relationship between a range of prices and the quantities 
demanded at those prices.

1. Demand curve
Demand curves can somewhat different for each product. 
They may appear relatively steep or flat, or they may be straight or curved. 
Nearly all demand curves share the fundamental similarity that they slope 
down from left to right. 
2. Supply curve
Quantity supplied means the amount of some good or service a producer is 
willing to supply at each price. 
Price is what the producer receives for selling one unit of a good or service. 
A rise in price almost always leads to an increase in the quantity supplied of 
that good or service, while a fall in price will decrease the quantity supplied.

4. Equilibrium
The word “equilibrium” means “balance.” 
If a market is at its equilibrium price and quantity, then it has no reason to 
move away from that point. 
However, if a market is not at equilibrium, then economic pressures arise to 
move the market toward the equilibrium price and the equilibrium quantity.
4. Equilibrium
In 1890, the famous economist Alfred Marshall wrote that asking whether 
supply or demand determined a price was like arguing
“whether it is the upper or the 
under blade of a pair of 
scissors that cuts a piece of 
paper.” 

5. Shift of demand curve
Price, however, is not the only thing that influences demand and supply.
What if overall consumer’s income has changed? 
Sometime preferences can be suddenly changed.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected?

5. Shift of demand curve
Does the higher income always bring greater demand?
A product whose demand rises when income rises is called a normal good.
but, there is a few exceptions to this pattern do exist. 
A product whose demand falls when income rises is called an inferior good. 
5. Shift of demand curve
And, for some goods such as luxury cars, fine cuisines, or jewelry, the effect of 
a rise in income can be especially pronounced.
We called those luxury goods.
A luxury good is a good for which demand increases more than proportionally 
as income rises, 
5. Shift of demand curve
Of course, income is not the only factor that causes a shift in demand.
We can think about some of other factors that shift demand curves.
One of those is changing tastes or preferences.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
It might cause a severe avoiding to eat chickens.
5. Shift of demand curve
Demographic changes can also be a important factor.
Actually, the demographic changes is combined with the changes in preference.
Since the consumption preference of youth and old person is quite different, 
changes in the demographic structure directly affects the overall preference of 
the society.
5. Shift of demand curve
Another example is the housing demand.
Since the demand for owning houses is usually peaked in the middle age about 
40s, the overall housing demand can also be peaked, when the number of 
middle-aged in the country is the highest level.
Some economists have tried to predict the future housing prices by using 
predictable demographic changes.
Mankiw, N. G., & Weil, D. N. (1989). The baby boom, the baby bust, and the 
housing market. Regional science and urban economics, 19(2), 235-258.
5. Shift of demand curve
It is also true that expectations about the future price (or expectations about 
tastes and preferences, income, and so on) can affect demand.
For example, if people hear that a hurricane is coming, they may rush to the 
store to buy flashlight batteries and bottled water. 
These changes can push the demand curve to the right.
5. Shift of demand curve
One interest thing is that some goods can be seriously affected by the 
expectation.
For example, we can think about housing market.
Demand for housing is not only determined  by preferences, but also by the 
expectations for capital gain.
This feature of housing markets sometimes causes speculations in housing 
markets.
6. Shift of supply curve
How about the supply curves? 
One of most important factor affecting the supply curve might be the 
production cost.
If a firm faces lower costs of production, a firm’s profits go up. This can be 
shown by the supply curve shifting to the right.
if a firm faces higher costs of production, then it will earn lower profits at any 
given selling price for its products. In this case, the supply curve shifts to the 
left.

When producers develops or discovers a technology that allows the firm to 
produce at a lower cost, the supply curve will shift to the right, as well. 
Think about the cost of raising a chicken in chicken farm and the poultry

6. Shift of supply curve
Government policies also can affect the cost of production and the supply 
curve through taxes, regulations, and subsidies.
A subsidy occurs when the government pays a firm directly or reduces the 
firm’s taxes if the firm carries out certain actions. 
From the firm’s perspective, taxes or regulations are an additional cost of 
production that shifts supply to the left, leading the firm to produce a lower 
quantity at every given price. 
So, government subsidies reduce the cost of production and increase supply at 
every given price, shifting supply to the right.

• People desire goods and services for the satisfaction or utility from using those goods and services.

2. Utility
• It is a general pattern that consumption of the first few units of good tends to bring a higher level of 
utility than consumption of later units.
• Suppose that you are in thirsty. You can compare the degree to which the first few drops of water relieve 
the thirst and the extent to which the drinking water later resolves the thirst.
• Economists refer to this pattern as the law of diminishing marginal utility.
• It means that, the utility of a person receives from consuming the first unit of a good is typically more 
than the utility received from consuming the fifth or the tenth unit of that same good.

• The law of diminishing marginal utility explains why people and societies rarely make all-or-nothing 
choices. 
• Most of people would not say, “My favorite food is potato, so I will eat nothing but only potatoes from 
now on.”
• Even if you get a very high level of utility from your favorite food, if you ate it exclusively, the marginal 
utility from those last few servings would not be very high.

Price, however, is not the only thing that influences demand and supply.
What if overall consumer’s income has changed? 
Sometime preferences can be suddenly changed.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected?

5. Shift of demand curve
Does the higher income always bring greater demand?
A product whose demand rises when income rises is called a normal good.
but, there is a few exceptions to this pattern do exist. 
A product whose demand falls when income rises is called an inferior good. 
5. Shift of demand curve
And, for some goods such as luxury cars, fine cuisines, or jewelry, the effect of 
a rise in income can be especially pronounced.
We called those luxury goods.
A luxury good is a good for which demand increases more than proportionally 
as income rises, 
5. Shift of demand curve
Of course, income is not the only factor that causes a shift in demand.
We can think about some of other factors that shift demand curves.
One of those is changing tastes or preferences.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
It might cause a severe avoiding to eat chickens.
5. Shift of demand curve
Demographic changes can also be a important factor.
Actually, the demographic changes is combined with the changes in preference.
Since the consumption preference of youth and old person is quite different, 
changes in the demographic structure directly affects the overall preference of 
the society.
5. Shift of demand curve
Another example is the housing demand.
Since the demand for owning houses is usually peaked in the middle age about 
40s, the overall housing demand can also be peaked, when the number of 
middle-aged in the country is the highest level.
Some economists have tried to predict the future housing prices by using 
predictable demographic changes.
Mankiw, N. G., & Weil, D. N. (1989). The baby boom, the baby bust, and the 
housing market. Regional science and urban economics, 19(2), 235-258.
5. Shift of demand curve
It is also true that expectations about the future price (or expectations about 
tastes and preferences, income, and so on) can affect demand.
For example, if people hear that a hurricane is coming, they may rush to the 
store to buy flashlight batteries and bottled water. 
These changes can push the demand curve to the right.
5. Shift of demand curve
One interest thing is that some goods can be seriously affected by the 
expectation.
For example, we can think about housing market.
Demand for housing is not only determined  by preferences, but also by the 
expectations for capital gain.
This feature of housing markets sometimes causes speculations in housing 
markets.
6. Shift of supply curve
How about the supply curves? 
One of most important factor affecting the supply curve might be the 
production cost.
If a firm faces lower costs of production, a firm’s profits go up. This can be 
shown by the supply curve shifting to the right.
if a firm faces higher costs of production, then it will earn lower profits at any 
given selling price for its products. In this case, the supply curve shifts to the 
left.
6. Shift of supply curve

6. Shift of supply curve
Several other things affect the cost of production, too. 
We can think about new technologies for production, and some government 
policies.
6. Shift of supply curve
When producers develops or discovers a technology that allows the firm to 
produce at a lower cost, the supply curve will shift to the right, as well. 
Think about the cost of raising a chicken in chicken farm and the poultry 
factory system.
6. Shift of supply curve
Government policies also can affect the cost of production and the supply 
curve through taxes, regulations, and subsidies.
A subsidy occurs when the government pays a firm directly or reduces the 
firm’s taxes if the firm carries out certain actions. 
From the firm’s perspective, taxes or regulations are an additional cost of 
production that shifts supply to the left, leading the firm to produce a lower 
quantity at every given price. 
So, government subsidies reduce the cost of production and increase supply at 
every given price, shifting supply to the right.

It implies alternative policy tools can often achieve the desired goals of price 
control laws, while avoiding at least some of their costs and tradeoffs.

documentContent.content: 소비자 문제
개별 소비자는 어떻게 선택을 하는가? 이 강의에서는 경제 모형을 경험하고, 예산 제약과 기회비용의 개념을 이해하며, 효용과 한계효용의 개념을 파악하고, 한계 분석을 통해 소비자의 최적화 문제를 해결하며, 최적 소비 결정의 특징을 학습하고, 수요 곡선을 도출하는 것을 목표로 합니다.
학습 목표
경제 모형을 경험한다.
예산 제약과 기회비용의 개념을 이해한다.
효용과 한계효용의 개념을 이해한다.
한계 분석을 통해 소비자의 최적화 문제를 해결한다.
최적 소비 결정의 특징을 학습한다.
수요 곡선을 도출한다.
서론
1. 모델 설명
소비자가 무엇을 선택할 수 있는가? (예산 제약)
소비자의 목표는 무엇인가? (효용 함수)
소비자는 어떻게 행동하는가? (제약 하에서의 목표 극대화, 합리성)
2. 예산 제약 하의 효용 극대화
한계 분석
3. 수요 곡선 도출
1. 예산 제약 (Budget Constraint)
소비자는 필요한 것과 원하는 것에 지출할 수 있는 소득이 제한되어 있다는 것을 파악하고자 합니다. 예를 들어, 페페라는 소비자는 매주 5,600원의 지출 예산을 가지고 있습니다. 그는 이 돈을 식권과 셔츠 구매에 배분할 수 있습니다. 식권은 한 장당 700원, 셔츠는 한 벌당 1,400원입니다.
두 가지 재화만 포함하는 예산 제약 다이어그램은 현실적이지 않습니다. 현대 경제에서는 사람들이 수천 가지의 재화를 선택하기 때문입니다. 그러나 여러 재화를 포함하는 모델에 대한 사고는 여기서 논의된 내용의 간단한 확장일 뿐입니다. 요점은 결정에는 항상 상충 관계(trade-off) 문제가 있다는 것입니다.

예산 제약선 위의 각 점은 식권과 셔츠의 조합을 나타내며, 이 조합의 총 비용은 페페의 예산인 5,600원과 같습니다. 만약 그가 예산을 모두 지출한다면, 그의 예산 제약은 색칠된 영역의 바깥선이 됩니다. 만약 그가 무제한의 소득을 가지고 있거나 재화가 무료라면, 그는 무제한으로 소비할 수 있을 것입니다. 제약선 밖의 어떤 점도 감당할 수 없습니다. 왜냐하면 페페의 예산보다 더 많은 돈이 들기 때문입니다.
이는 간단히 말해 소득 = 지출을 의미합니다. 이 경우 소득은 5,600원이고 지출은 700M(식권) + 1,400S(셔츠)이므로, 5600 = 700M + 1400S 입니다. 이를 2차원 평면에 그리기 위해 M에 대해 정리하면 M = 8 - 2S가 됩니다.
예산 제약선의 기울기는 상대 가격에 의해 결정됩니다. 상대 가격은 페페가 예산 내에서 셔츠 한 벌을 더 얻기 위해 얼마나 많은 식권을 포기해야 하는지를 나타냅니다. 예산 집합을 따라가 보면, 셔츠 1벌을 얻는 것은 식권 2장을 포기하는 것을 의미합니다.
경제학자들은 이를 기회비용이라고 부릅니다. 기회비용은 무엇을 얻기 위해 무엇을 포기해야 하는지를 나타냅니다. 즉, 기회비용은 차선의 대안의 가치입니다. 페페에게 셔츠 1벌의 기회비용은 식권 2장입니다. 그는 추가 셔츠의 가치가 대안(식권 2장)의 가치를 초과한다면 셔츠를 한 벌 더 구매하기로 결정할 것입니다.
경제학의 근본 원리 중 하나는 모든 선택에는 기회비용이 있다는 것입니다. 경제학 수업에 늦잠을 자는 경우, 기회비용은 수업을 보충하는 데 쓰일 시간일 수 있습니다. 특정 사람과 결혼을 선택하면 다른 사람과 결혼할 기회를 포기하는 것입니다. 요컨대, 기회비용은 우리 주변에 항상 존재하며 인간 존재의 일부입니다.

많은 경우, 기회비용을 가격으로 지칭하는 것이 합리적입니다. 예를 들어, 대학원 진학은 기회비용이 금전적 비용을 초과하는 경우입니다. 대학 진학의 명시적 비용은 등록금, 책, 숙식 및 기타 비용일 수 있습니다. 하지만 수업에 참석하고 공부하는 시간 동안에는 유급 직업을 가질 수 없습니다. 따라서 대학원 진학은 직접적인 비용과 함께 소득 상실이라는 기회비용을 부과합니다.

만약 재화의 가격이 변한다면 어떻게 될까요? 예를 들어, 버스 티켓 가격이 1,400원으로 인상되었다고 가정해 봅시다. 버스 티켓 가격 인상은 라면 구매 능력에는 영향을 미치지 않지만, 페페가 구매할 수 있는 버스 티켓 수를 줄일 것입니다. 예산 제약선은 어떻게 변할까요? 다시 그려보면, 식권 = 4 - 셔츠로 기울기가 변하게 됩니다. 만약 페페의 소득이 절반(2,800원)으로 줄어든다면, 그는 식권과 셔츠 모두를 더 적게 구매할 수 있게 되어 예산 제약선이 원점 쪽으로 평행 이동합니다.
2. 효용 (Utility)
사람들은 재화와 서비스를 사용함으로써 얻는 만족감, 즉 효용 때문에 재화와 서비스를 원합니다. 효용은 경제학자들이 어떤 사람의 선택에 대한 만족도/유용성 또는 행복 수준을 설명하는 데 사용하는 용어입니다. 물론 일상생활에서는 그러한 것을 측정하지 않지만, 모델에서는 각 개인의 내재된 유인 구조를 복제하는 데 매우 유용한 도구가 될 수 있습니다.
경제학자들은 효용의 특징을 가정합니다. 첫째, 어떤 재화를 더 많이 소비할수록 더 많은 효용을 얻습니다. 둘째, 사람이 재화를 더 많이 소비할수록 추가적인 (또는 한계) 단위에서 얻는 효용은 감소합니다.

재화의 처음 몇 단위를 소비하는 것이 나중 단위를 소비하는 것보다 더 높은 수준의 효용을 가져오는 경향이 있다는 것은 일반적인 패턴입니다. 예를 들어, 목마를 때 처음 몇 모금의 물이 갈증을 해소하는 정도와 나중에 마시는 물이 갈증을 해소하는 정도를 비교할 수 있습니다. 경제학자들은 이 패턴을 한계효용 체감의 법칙이라고 부릅니다. 이는 사람이 재화의 첫 단위를 소비함으로써 얻는 효용이 일반적으로 동일한 재화의 다섯 번째 또는 열 번째 단위에서 얻는 효용보다 크다는 것을 의미합니다.

한계효용 체감의 법칙은 왜 사람들과 사회가 전부 아니면 전무(all-or-nothing)한 선택을 거의 하지 않는지 설명합니다. 대부분의 사람들은 "가장 좋아하는 음식이 감자이니, 이제부터 감자만 먹을 거야"라고 말하지 않을 것입니다. 가장 좋아하는 음식에서 매우 높은 수준의 효용을 얻더라도, 그것만 먹는다면 마지막 몇 인분에서 얻는 한계효용은 그리 높지 않을 것입니다.
식권(및 셔츠)의 한계효용 예시: MUM = 1/M, MUS = 1/S
최적의 선택
한계 분석 (Marginal Analysis)

한계 접근 방식은 한 재화를 덜 소비하고 다른 재화를 더 소비하는 것의 상충 관계(지출당 한계효용으로 측정)를 살펴보는 것에 기반합니다. X의 한계효용은 X의 1단위(우리가 상상할 수 있는 가장 작은 단위)를 추가로 소비함으로써 얻는 추가적인 효용입니다. 어떤 결정이 더 나을까요? 한계효용을 확인해야 합니다. 그러나 가격이 다르다는 점을 고려해야 합니다. 상대 가격은 X 한 단위를 더 얻기 위해 Y 몇 단위를 교환할 수 있는지를 나타냅니다. X의 지출당 한계효용 = X의 한계효용 / X의 가격입니다.

어떤 결정이 더 나을까요? 지출당 한계효용을 비교하는 것입니다. 초기 상태 X, Y가 있다고 가정해 봅시다. 만약 (MUx / Px) > (MUy / Py) 이라면, 그/그녀는 (X, Y에 대한 결정을 변경함으로써) 더 나아질 수 있을까요? 예. Y를 일부 포기하고 X를 더 많이 얻는다고 가정해 봅시다. 만약 (MUx / Px) < (MUy / Py) 이라면 어떨까요? 모든 조정을 거친 후, 우리는 극대화 규칙인 MUx / Px = MUy / Py 를 도출합니다. 이 등식 조건에서 벗어날 유인이 없다는 점에 유의하십시오.

그/그녀가 0부터 돈을 쓰기 시작한다고 가정해 봅시다. 최선의 결정을 내리기 위해, 그/그녀는 지출당 한계효용이 더 높은 계획을 선택할 것입니다. 예를 들어, (MUx / Px) > (MUy / Py) 이라면, 그/그녀는 X를 선택할 것입니다. 한 재화의 한계효용은 더 많이 소비할수록 감소한다는 점에 유의하십시오. 만약 그/그녀가 X를 점점 더 많이 소비한다면, (MUx / Px) < (MUy / Py) 가 될 것입니다. 이 경우, 그/그녀는 Y를 더 많이 얻고 X를 일부 포기함으로써 더 많은 효용을 얻을 수 있습니다. 이는 그/그녀가 합리적이라면, MUx / Px = MUy / Py 조건을 고수할 것이라는 의미입니다.

다른 재화가 있다면 (즉, 더 일반적인 용어로), MUx / Px = MUy / Py = ⋯ = MUz / Pz 가 됩니다. 이 극대화 규칙은 시장 경제에서 소비자의 여러 중요한 특징을 포착합니다. 즉, 여러 품목에 대한 소비 간의 관계, 가격 변화의 효과, 소득 변화의 효과, 그리고 한계효용의 형태가 소비 계획에 어떻게 영향을 미치는지(그리고 소비 계획이 소득/가격 변화에 어떻게 반응하는지)를 보여줍니다.
예시: 페페의 최적 선택 (Example: Pepe's Optimal Choice)
예산 제약: 5600 = 700M + 1400S, 효용 함수: MUM = 1/M, MUS = 1/S. M, S에 대한 최적의 선택은 무엇일까요?
이제 소득이 11,200원으로 증가했다고 가정해 봅시다. 이 경우, 페페의 소득이 확대되면 예산 제약선이 바깥으로 평행 이동합니다.
소득 효과와 재화의 특성을 살펴보면, 정상재(Normal goods)는 소득 증가가 수요 증가(+)를 유발하고, 열등재(Inferior goods)는 소득 증가가 수요 감소(-)를 유발합니다. 사치재(Luxury goods)는 소득 증가가 수요의 더 큰 비율 증가(++)를 유발합니다.
만약 M의 가격이 1400원으로 오른다면 어떻게 될까요? 식권 = 4 - 셔츠로 기울기가 변합니다. S의 가격이 700원으로 떨어진다면? 식권 = 8 - 셔츠로 기울기가 변합니다.
가격이 변할 때, 대체 효과(Substitution effect)는 상대 가격의 변화(예산 제약선의 기울기)를 의미하며, 소득 효과(Income effect)는 실질 구매력의 변화를 의미합니다.
가격 효과(Price effect)는 가격 상승이 수요 감소(-)를 유발하는 것입니다. 특별한 경우로 기펜재(Giffen goods)는 가격 효과가 양수(+)입니다.

재화 간의 관계를 보면, 대체재(Substitute goods)는 A의 수요 증가가 B의 수요 감소(-)를 유발하고, 보완재(Complementary goods)는 A의 수요 증가가 B의 수요 증가(+)를 유발합니다. 그렇다면 다른 재화에 대한 가격 효과를 고려해 봅시다. 대체재에 대한 가격 효과는 A의 가격 상승이 B의 수요 증가(+)를 유발하고, 보완재에 대한 가격 효과는 A의 가격 상승이 B의 수요 감소(-)를 유발합니다.
수요 곡선 (Demand Curve)
수요 곡선이란 무엇일까요? 가격과 수요량 사이의 관계입니다. 수요량이란 무엇일까요? 소비자가 자신의 이익을 따를 때 무엇이 발생하는지 알고 있습니다. 즉, 소비의 최적 결정입니다. 가격 효과는 음수(-)라는 점을 상기하십시오.

aiNotes.summary: 이 문서는 소비자의 경제적 선택 문제를 다루며, 소비자가 직면하는 예산 제약, 효용과 한계효용의 개념, 그리고 효용을 극대화하기 위한 최적의 소비 결정을 설명합니다. 한계 분석을 통해 소비자의 합리적인 선택 규칙을 도출하고, 소득 및 가격 변화가 소비 결정에 미치는 영향(소득 효과, 대체 효과)을 분석합니다. 최종적으로 이러한 소비자 행동이 수요 곡선으로 어떻게 이어지는지를 설명하며, 한계효용 체감의 법칙과 기회비용과 같은 핵심 경제 개념들을 다룹니다.

keyConcepts.definition: 소비자가 주어진 소득으로 구매할 수 있는 재화와 서비스의 조합을 나타내는 한계.
어떤 선택을 함으로써 포기해야 하는 차선의 가치.
효용은 재화와 서비스 소비를 통해 얻는 만족도이며, 한계효용은 재화 한 단위를 추가 소비할 때 얻는 추가적인 만족도.
재화의 소비량이 증가할수록 추가적인 단위에서 얻는 한계효용이 감소하는 현상.
주어진 예산 제약 하에서 효용을 극대화하는 재화와 서비스의 조합을 찾는 문제로, 한계 분석을 통해 해결된다.

importantTerms.definition: 소비자가 주어진 소득으로 구매할 수 있는 재화와 서비스의 조합을 나타내는 한계선.
어떤 선택을 위해 포기해야 하는 차선책의 가치.
재화나 서비스를 소비함으로써 얻는 만족도나 행복 수준.

documentContent.content: 강의 3: 생산자 문제와 공급 곡선
Jengei Hong
시장 경제 시스템
시장 경제 시스템 내에서 다양한 기업(Firm1-Firm5)들이 상품 및 서비스 시장과 생산 요소 시장을 통해 상호작용합니다. 이 강의는 개별 기업이 어떻게 의사결정을 내리는지에 초점을 맞춥니다.
주요 용어
생산자의 최적 의사결정, 생산 비용, 고정 비용과 변동 비용, 평균 비용과 한계 비용, 생산 함수, 한계 생산 체감의 법칙, 총수입, 평균 수입, 한계 수입.
생산자의 최적화 문제
기업 또는 사업 부문은 노동, 자본, 토지, 원자재 또는 완제품 구성 요소와 같은 투입물을 결합하여 산출물을 생산합니다. 이러한 생산 활동은 제조뿐만 아니라 운송, 유통, 도매 및 소매 판매를 포함하여 가치를 창출하는 모든 과정이나 서비스를 포함합니다.
기업의 목표는 이윤 극대화입니다.
이윤, 수입 및 비용
이윤 = 수입 – 비용
수입 = 가격 × 수량
비용 = 기업이 제품을 만들고 판매하기 위해 지불하는 금액을 총비용이라고 합니다.
기업의 비용 구조는 몇 가지 공통적인 기본 패턴으로 나눌 수 있습니다. 단기적으로 비용을 고정 비용과 변동 비용으로 분류할 수 있습니다.
고정 비용은 단기적으로 변경할 수 없는 비용입니다.
변동 비용은 변경할 수 있는 비용입니다.
생산 비용의 구조

고정 비용은 생산 수준에 관계없이, 적어도 단기적으로는 변하지 않는 지출입니다. 예를 들어, 공장 건설 비용이나 중장비 구매 비용, 연구 개발 비용, 광고 비용 등이 있습니다. 고정 비용의 수준은 제품이나 산업의 특성에 따라 다릅니다. 예를 들어, 휴대폰이나 컴퓨터 칩을 제조하려면 비싼 공장이 필요하지만, 푸드 트럭이나 화가는 상대적으로 적은 고정 비용으로 운영할 수 있습니다.
변동 비용은 생산 활동에서 발생하는 비용입니다. 예를 들어, 임금과 중간재 구매 비용은 변동 비용입니다. 더 많이 생산할수록 변동 비용은 더 커집니다.
총비용 = 고정 비용 + 변동 비용.
생산의 본질
두 가지 가정:
1. 양성 (투입물에 대한 양의 관계)
2. 한계 생산 체감의 법칙
어떤 투입물의 한계 생산물: 해당 투입물 한 단위 추가로 얻는 산출물의 추가 수량.
예시: 페페의 치킨집
치킨집 운영의 고정 비용(공간 및 장비 포함)은 100이라고 가정합니다. 변동 비용은 직원을 고용하는 비용이며, 이 예시에서는 배달원 한 명당 50입니다. 변동 비용 = 투입물 가격 × 투입물 수량. 투입물(직원) 한 단위를 추가하면 비용은 투입물 가격(임금 50)만큼 증가합니다.
페페의 치킨집 비용 구조 및 수익 예시
노동 투입량에 따른 생산량, 총수입, 추가 수입, 고정 비용, 변동 비용, 총비용, 추가 비용을 보여주는 표가 제시됩니다. 치킨 한 마리당 가격은 30으로 가정됩니다. 노동 투입이 증가할수록 생산량은 증가하지만, 추가 노동자 한 명당 생산량 증가분은 점차 줄어들어 한계 생산 체감의 법칙을 보여줍니다.
최적의 선택은 무엇인가?
추가 노동자 한 명당 발생하는 추가 비용(한계 비용)은 50으로 일정하지만, 추가 노동자 한 명당 발생하는 추가 수입(한계 수입)은 생산량이 증가함에 따라 감소합니다. 이윤 극대화는 한계 수입(MR)과 한계 비용(MC)이 같아지는 지점에서 발생합니다.
생산 함수
생산 비용에 대해 생산 테이블을 사용하여 논의했습니다. 이제 생산 테이블 대신 생산 함수를 사용할 수 있습니다. 그리고 생산 함수로부터 각 비용 함수를 도출할 수 있습니다.
효용 함수와 마찬가지로 생산 함수의 형태는 일반적으로 가정됩니다. 이 경우, 한계 생산 체감 패턴을 가진 생산 함수를 가정합니다. 왜냐하면 이 형태는 경제학자들이 일반적으로 사용하는 생산 함수의 기본 형태 중 하나이기 때문입니다.
수학적 준비
함수

함수는 X와 Y 사이의 특별한 관계 유형입니다. X의 모든 요소를 Y의 정확히 하나의 요소에 투영합니다. 표기법: y = F(x). 예시: y = x + 10, y = 2x^α. 함수를 그리는 것은 함수의 특성을 스케치하는 데 도움이 됩니다. (α가 0 < α < 1일 때와 α > 1일 때의 y 특징을 설명합니다.) 일반적으로 수평(수직) 축은 투입(산출) 변수를 나타냅니다.
미분 개념
x의 변화에 대한 y의 변화의 반응성을 확인합니다. 함수의 기울기 의미. 미분과 도함수 함수. 표기법: dy/dx, dF(x)/dx, F'(x).
미분 공식
상수의 미분: dA/dx = 0
멱함수의 미분: d(Ax^α)/dx = αAx^(α-1)
합의 미분: d(F(x) + Z(x))/dx = dF(x)/dx + dZ(x)/dx
예시 2: 생산 함수
페페의 치킨집 생산 함수의 형태를 Q = 10X^(1/2)로 가정합니다. 여기서 Q는 산출량이고 X는 투입량(고용 인원)입니다.
생산자의 최적화 문제 (재검토)
이윤 = 수입 – 비용임을 상기합니다. 이제 비용과 수입을 함수로 설명합니다. 생산 비용 및 생산의 한계 비용, 수입 및 한계 수입.
생산 비용 함수 정리
생산 비용(생산량에 대한): 해당 수량을 생산하는 데 지불된 비용. 총비용 = 고정 비용 + 변동 비용(=투입물 가격 * 투입물). 생산 비용 = 고정 비용 + 투입물 가격 * 해당 제품을 생산하는 데 필요한 투입물.
예시 2: 생산 비용 함수 및 한계 비용
예시에서 Q = 10X^(1/2)이므로 X = Q^2/100입니다. 생산 비용(Q를 생산하는 데 드는) = 100 + 50 * (Q^2/100)입니다. 한계 비용은 Q에 대한 생산 비용의 도함수이므로 MC = Q입니다.
수입과 한계 수입
수입 = 가격 × 수량. 한계 수입: 제품 한 단위를 더 생산하고 판매함으로써 얻는 추가 수입 = 가격. 이를 해결하려면 가격의 성격을 가정해야 합니다. 간단하게, 가격은 10으로 고정되어 있다고 가정합니다. 이 경우 한계 수입은 10입니다.
생산자의 최적화 문제: 이윤 극대화
이윤 극대화 규칙: 한계 수입 = 한계 비용. 예시에서 한계 수입 = 10이고 한계 비용 = Q입니다. 따라서 MR=MC는 Q = 10을 의미합니다. 그러므로 최적 생산량은 10입니다.
산출량과 비용의 관계
생산 과정에서 한계 생산물이 체감합니다. 따라서 투입물 한 단위 추가에 대한 산출량 변화량은 감소합니다. 이는 산출물 한 단위를 추가로 생산하는 데 필요한 추가 투입량은 증가한다는 것과 같습니다. 이는 산출물 한 단위를 더 생산하는 데 드는 비용이 증가한다는 것을 의미합니다.
생산 비용의 구조: 4가지 비용 개념
평균 총비용, 평균 고정 비용, 평균 변동 비용, 한계 비용.
평균 고정 비용 (AFC)
평균 고정 비용(AFC)은 고정 비용을 산출량으로 나눈 것입니다. AFC = 고정 비용 / 산출량. 산출량이 증가할수록 AFC는 지속적으로 감소하는 형태를 가집니다.
평균 변동 비용 (AVC)
평균 변동 비용(AVC)은 총 변동 비용을 산출량으로 나눈 것입니다. AVC = 총 변동 비용 / 산출량. AVC는 처음에는 감소하다가 어느 시점부터 증가하는 U자 형태를 가집니다.
평균 총비용 (ATC)
평균 총비용(ATC)은 총비용을 산출량으로 나눈 것입니다. ATC = 총비용 / 산출량 = (고정 비용 + 변동 비용) / 산출량. ATC 또한 U자 형태를 가집니다.
한계 비용 (MC)
한계 비용(MC)은 산출물 한 단위를 더 생산하는 데 드는 추가 비용입니다. MC = 총비용 변화량 / 산출량 변화량. 예를 들어, 생산량이 10마리에서 18마리 치킨으로 증가할 때 총비용은 50 증가합니다 (따라서 치킨 한 마리당 한계 비용은 50/8이 됩니다). MC 곡선은 일반적으로 우상향하는 형태를 가집니다.
ATC와 MC의 관계
100m 달리기 선수가 자신의 기록을 세고 있다고 가정해 봅시다. 10개 기록의 평균이 10초였고, 11번째 기록이 9초였다고 가정해 봅시다. 그의 평균 기록은 어떻게 바뀔까요? 약간 내려갈 것입니다. 하지만 11번째 기록이 이전 평균보다 큰 11초였다면, 추가 기록을 포함한 평균 기록은 올라갈 것입니다.
ATC는 평균 기록과 유사한 개념이며, MC는 11번째 새 기록과 유사한 개념입니다. 평균 총비용은 한계 비용이 평균 총비용보다 크면 증가하고, 작으면 감소합니다. 결과적으로 MC 곡선은 ATC 곡선의 최저점을 통과하여 올라갑니다.
연습 문제
생산 함수의 형태를 Q = 2X^(1/2)로 가정합니다. 여기서 Q는 산출량이고 X는 투입량입니다. 고정 비용은 100이고, 각 투입물(변동 비용)의 가격은 10이라고 가정합니다.
1. 투입량에 대한 총비용 함수를 도출하시오.
2. 산출량에 대한 총비용 함수를 도출하시오.
3. 평균 고정 비용 방정식을 도출하시오.
4. 평균 변동 비용 방정식을 도출하시오.
5. 평균 총비용 방정식을 도출하시오.
6. 산출량에 대한 한계 비용 방정식을 도출하시오.

documentContent.content: 서론
이번 주에는 다음 내용을 학습합니다:
- 재화 및 서비스 시장에서의 수요, 공급, 그리고 균형
- 수요 및 공급 곡선의 이동
- 균형 가격 및 수량의 변화
- 가격 상한제 및 가격 하한제
시장 균형
경제학의 개념인 시장 균형은 기업(Firm 1~5)들이 재화 및 서비스 시장과 생산 요소 시장을 통해 상호작용하는 구조를 포함합니다.
1. 수요 곡선
수요는 소비자들이 각 가격 수준에서 구매할 의사와 능력이 있는 재화나 서비스의 양을 의미합니다.
각 재화와 서비스에 대한 수요는 개별 소비자의 선호도와 예산에 의해 결정될 수 있습니다. 수요는 사회의 지불 의사(willingness to pay)를 나타냅니다.
1.1. 수요와 수요량의 구분
특정 가격에서 구매되는 총 단위 수를 수요량(quantity demanded)이라고 합니다. 따라서 경제학 용어에서 수요(demand)는 수요량과 동일하지 않습니다.
수요는 다양한 가격 범위와 그 가격에서 요구되는 수량 간의 관계를 의미합니다.
1.2. 수요의 법칙
경제학자들은 가격과 수요량 사이의 이러한 역(inverse) 관계를 수요의 법칙(law of demand)이라고 부릅니다. 수요의 법칙은 수요에 영향을 미치는 다른 모든 변수들이 일정하게 유지된다고 가정합니다.
(수요 곡선은 일반적으로 가격(P)이 높을수록 수요량(Q)이 감소하는 형태를 보입니다.)
1.3. 수요 곡선의 특성
수요 곡선은 각 제품마다 다소 다를 수 있습니다. 상대적으로 가파르거나 완만하게 나타날 수 있으며, 직선이거나 곡선일 수도 있습니다. 거의 모든 수요 곡선은 왼쪽에서 오른쪽으로 아래로 기울어진다는 근본적인 유사성을 공유합니다.
2. 공급 곡선
공급량(quantity supplied)은 생산자가 각 가격 수준에서 공급할 의사가 있는 재화나 서비스의 양을 의미합니다.
가격은 생산자가 재화나 서비스 한 단위를 판매하여 받는 금액입니다. 가격 상승은 거의 항상 해당 재화나 서비스의 공급량 증가로 이어지며, 가격 하락은 공급량을 감소시킵니다.
(공급 곡선은 일반적으로 가격(P)이 높을수록 공급량(Q)이 증가하는 형태를 보입니다.)

aiNotes.summary: 본 문서는 시장의 기본 개념인 수요와 공급을 설명합니다. 수요는 소비자의 구매 의사와 능력을 나타내며, 수요량과의 차이점과 가격과의 역관계를 설명하는 '수요의 법칙'을 다룹니다. 또한, 수요 곡선의 일반적인 특성(우하향)을 제시합니다. 공급은 생산자가 각 가격에서 공급할 의사가 있는 양을 의미하며, 가격 상승이 공급량 증가로 이어진다는 점을 강조합니다.

documentContent.content: 3. 불균형 – 초과 공급
초과 공급은 시장 가격이 균형 가격보다 높을 때 발생합니다. 이 경우, 공급량(예: 1200)이 수요량(예: 800)을 초과하여 시장에 팔리지 않는 재고가 쌓이게 됩니다. 예를 들어, 치킨집에서 닭을 팔 수 없어 생닭, 기름, 밀가루 같은 원재료가 창고에서 상하기 시작하는 상황을 들 수 있습니다.
이러한 상황에서 일부 치킨집은 가격을 인하하려 할 것입니다. 이는 전혀 팔지 못하는 것보다 낮은 가격이라도 판매하는 것이 낫기 때문입니다. 따라서 가격이 균형 수준보다 높을 때, 수요와 공급 구조에 내재된 유인에 의해 가격이 균형을 향해 하락하도록 압력이 발생합니다.
3. 불균형 – 초과 수요
초과 수요는 시장 가격이 균형 가격보다 낮을 때 발생합니다. 이 경우, 수요량(예: 1200)이 공급량(예: 800)을 초과하여 소비자들이 원하는 만큼 상품을 구매할 수 없는 상황이 됩니다. 예를 들어, 소비자들이 치킨 주문을 기다리고 있지만, 치킨집들은 주문이 밀려 재고가 부족하다고 말하는 상황을 들 수 있습니다.
이러한 상황에서 치킨집들은 가격을 인상하더라도 재고를 모두 팔 수 있다는 것을 쉽게 알 수 있습니다. 따라서 가격이 균형 수준보다 낮을 때, 수요와 공급 구조에 내재된 유인에 의해 가격이 균형을 향해 상승하도록 압력이 발생합니다.
4. 균형
시장 균형은 수요량과 공급량이 일치하는 상태를 의미합니다. 이 지점에서는 가격과 수량이 안정적이며, 시장은 더 이상 움직일 이유가 없습니다. 텍스트에서는 균형 수량(Q*)이 1000, 균형 가격(P*)이 15000으로 제시된 바와 같이, 수요 곡선과 공급 곡선이 만나는 지점에서 균형이 이루어집니다.
'균형(equilibrium)'이라는 단어는 '균형(balance)'을 의미합니다. 시장이 균형 가격과 수량에 도달하면, 그 지점에서 벗어날 이유가 없습니다. 그러나 시장이 균형 상태가 아니면, 시장을 균형 가격과 균형 수량으로 이동시키려는 경제적 압력이 발생합니다.
1890년, 유명한 경제학자 알프레드 마샬은 공급이나 수요 중 어느 것이 가격을 결정하는지에 대해 묻는 것은 마치 “가위를 이루는 윗날과 아랫날 중 어느 것이 종이를 자르는지 논쟁하는 것과 같다”고 비유했습니다. 이는 시장 가격 결정에 있어 수요와 공급이 모두 필수적인 역할을 한다는 것을 강조하는 것입니다.

documentContent.content: 5. 수요 곡선 이동
가격만이 수요와 공급에 영향을 미치는 유일한 요소는 아닙니다. 예를 들어, 전반적인 소비자 소득이 변하거나 선호도가 갑자기 바뀔 수도 있습니다. 조류독감이 발생하면 닭고기 수요는 어떻게 영향을 받을까요?
다음 그래프는 수요 곡선의 이동을 보여줍니다. (Q: 수량, P: 가격, D0: 초기 수요 곡선, D1: 우측으로 이동한 수요 곡선, D2: 좌측으로 이동한 수요 곡선)
소득이 증가하면 항상 수요가 증가할까요? 소득이 증가할 때 수요가 증가하는 상품을 정상재(normal good)라고 합니다. 그러나 예외도 존재합니다. 소득이 증가할 때 수요가 감소하는 상품을 열등재(inferior good)라고 합니다.
고급 자동차, 고급 요리, 보석과 같은 일부 재화의 경우 소득 증가의 영향이 특히 두드러질 수 있습니다. 이러한 재화를 사치재(luxury good)라고 부릅니다. 사치재는 소득이 증가할 때 수요가 소득 증가율보다 비례적으로 더 크게 증가하는 재화입니다.
물론, 소득만이 수요 곡선 이동을 야기하는 유일한 요인은 아닙니다. 수요 곡선을 이동시키는 다른 요인들을 고려해 볼 수 있습니다. 그 중 하나는 취향이나 선호도의 변화입니다. 예를 들어, 조류독감이 발생하면 닭고기 수요는 어떻게 영향을 받을까요? 이는 닭고기 섭취를 심각하게 기피하게 만들 수 있습니다.
인구통계학적 변화 또한 중요한 요인이 될 수 있습니다. 실제로 인구통계학적 변화는 선호도 변화와 결합됩니다. 청년층과 노년층의 소비 선호도는 상당히 다르기 때문에, 인구 구조의 변화는 사회 전반의 선호도에 직접적인 영향을 미칩니다.

또 다른 예시는 주택 수요입니다. 주택 소유 수요는 일반적으로 40대 중년층에서 절정에 달하기 때문에, 한 국가의 중년층 인구 수가 최고 수준일 때 전체 주택 수요도 정점을 찍을 수 있습니다. 일부 경제학자들은 예측 가능한 인구통계학적 변화를 이용하여 미래 주택 가격을 예측하려고 시도했습니다. (Mankiw, N. G., & Weil, D. N. (1989). The baby boom, the baby bust, and the housing market. Regional science and urban economics, 19(2), 235-258.)
미래 가격 (또는 취향, 선호도, 소득 등에 대한 기대)에 대한 기대 또한 수요에 영향을 미칠 수 있습니다. 예를 들어, 사람들이 허리케인이 온다는 소식을 들으면 손전등 배터리와 생수를 사기 위해 상점으로 달려갈 수 있습니다. 이러한 변화는 수요 곡선을 오른쪽으로 밀어낼 수 있습니다.
흥미로운 점은 일부 재화는 기대에 의해 심각하게 영향을 받을 수 있다는 것입니다. 예를 들어, 주택 시장을 생각해 볼 수 있습니다. 주택 수요는 선호도뿐만 아니라 자본 이득에 대한 기대에 의해서도 결정됩니다. 주택 시장의 이러한 특징은 때때로 주택 시장에서 투기를 유발합니다.
6. 공급 곡선 이동
공급 곡선은 어떨까요? 공급 곡선에 영향을 미치는 가장 중요한 요인 중 하나는 생산 비용일 것입니다. 기업이 생산 비용이 낮아지면 기업의 이윤은 증가합니다. 이는 공급 곡선이 오른쪽으로 이동하는 것으로 나타날 수 있습니다. 기업이 생산 비용이 높아지면 제품의 특정 판매 가격에서 더 낮은 이윤을 얻게 됩니다. 이 경우 공급 곡선은 왼쪽으로 이동합니다.
다음 그래프는 공급 곡선의 이동을 보여줍니다. (Q: 수량, P: 가격, S0: 초기 공급 곡선, S1: 우측으로 이동한 공급 곡선, S2: 좌측으로 이동한 공급 곡선)
몇 가지 다른 요인들도 생산 비용에 영향을 미칩니다. 생산을 위한 신기술과 일부 정부 정책을 고려해 볼 수 있습니다.
생산자가 기업이 더 낮은 비용으로 생산할 수 있도록 하는 기술을 개발하거나 발견하면 공급 곡선도 오른쪽으로 이동할 것입니다. 양계장에서 닭을 기르는 비용과 가금류 공장 시스템을 생각해 보십시오.

정부 정책 또한 세금, 규제, 보조금을 통해 생산 비용과 공급 곡선에 영향을 미칠 수 있습니다. 보조금은 정부가 특정 조치를 수행하는 기업에 직접 지불하거나 기업의 세금을 감면해 주는 경우 발생합니다. 기업의 관점에서 세금이나 규제는 공급을 왼쪽으로 이동시켜 특정 가격에서 기업이 더 적은 양을 생산하게 만드는 추가적인 생산 비용입니다. 따라서 정부 보조금은 생산 비용을 줄이고 특정 가격에서 공급을 증가시켜 공급을 오른쪽으로 이동시킵니다.

aiNotes.summary: 본 문서는 수요 및 공급 곡선 이동의 주요 요인들을 설명합니다. 수요 곡선은 소비자 소득(정상재, 열등재, 사치재), 취향/선호도 변화, 인구통계학적 변화, 그리고 미래에 대한 기대에 의해 이동합니다. 공급 곡선은 주로 생산 비용에 의해 이동하며, 이는 신기술과 정부 정책(세금, 규제, 보조금)의 영향을 받습니다. 생산 비용이 낮아지면 공급 곡선은 우측으로, 높아지면 좌측으로 이동합니다.

documentContent.content: 1. 가격 통제 개요
어떤 경우에는 가격에 대한 불만이 정치인에 대한 대중의 압력으로 이어지기도 합니다. 정부가 가격을 규제하기 위해 제정하는 법률을 '가격 통제(Price controls)'라고 합니다.
가격 통제는 크게 두 가지 방식으로 나뉩니다. 하나는 가격이 특정 수준 이상으로 오르지 못하게 하는 '가격 상한제(Price ceiling)'이고, 다른 하나는 가격이 특정 수준 이하로 떨어지지 못하게 하는 '가격 하한제(Price floor)'입니다.
2. 가격 상한제
가격 상한제는 가격이 일정 수준 이상으로 상승하는 것을 법적으로 제한하는 조치입니다. (관련 그래프는 본문에서 Q, P, 1000, 18000, 15000, E0, E1, 1200 등의 표기로 제시됨)
3. 가격 하한제
가격 하한제는 시장에서 지불될 수 있는 가장 낮은 합법적인 가격을 의미합니다. 가격 하한제는 때때로 '가격 지지(price supports)'라고도 불리는데, 이는 가격이 특정 수준 이하로 떨어지는 것을 막아 가격을 지지하는 역할을 하기 때문입니다. (관련 그래프는 본문에서 Q, P, 1000, 15000, E2, 1500, E’ 등의 표기로 제시됨)
4. 가격 통제의 결과 및 대안
수요와 공급 모델은 가격 통제 법규가 제공하는 유인에 사람들과 기업이 어떻게 반응하는지를 보여줍니다. 그 결과, 가격 통제는 종종 바람직하지 않은 결과를 초래할 수 있습니다.
이는 가격 통제 법률의 목표를 달성하면서도 그 비용과 상충 관계 중 일부를 피할 수 있는 대안적인 정책 도구가 종종 더 효과적일 수 있음을 시사합니다.

aiNotes.summary: 본문은 정부의 시장 개입 방식 중 하나인 '가격 통제'에 대해 설명합니다. 가격 통제는 가격 상한제와 가격 하한제의 두 가지 유형으로 나뉘며, 각각 특정 가격 수준 이상 또는 이하로 가격이 형성되는 것을 막는 역할을 합니다. 이러한 가격 통제는 수요와 공급 모델에 따라 시장에 영향을 미치며, 종종 바람직하지 않은 결과를 초래할 수 있으므로, 대안적인 정책 도구의 필요성을 강조합니다.

1. Budget Constraint
• Economists call it opportunity cost.
• Opportunity cost indicate what have to be given up to obtain something. In other words, opportunity cost 
is the value of the next best alternative.
• For Pepe, the opportunity cost of 1 shirt is the 2 meal tickets. 
• He would decide to buy one more shirt, If the value of the extra shirt exceed the value of the alternative 
(2 meal tickets).
1. Budget Constraint
• A fundamental principle of economics is that every choice has an opportunity cost.
• If you sleep through your economics class, the opportunity cost might be the time which would be spent 
to make up the class.
• If you choose to marry one person, you give up the opportunity to marry anyone else. 
• In short, opportunity cost is all around us and part of human existence.
1. Budget Constraint
• In many cases, it is reasonable to refer to the opportunity cost as the price.
• For example, attending graduate school is the case where the opportunity cost exceeds the monetary cost. 
The explicit costs of attending college might be about tuition, books, room and board, and other expenses. 
But in addition, during the hours that you are attending class and studying, it is impossible to work at a 
paying job. Thus, graduate school imposes both an out-of-pocket cost and an opportunity cost of lost 
earnings.

2. Utility
• People desire goods and services for the satisfaction or utility from using those goods and services.
• Utility is the term which economists use to describe a person’s level of satisfaction/usefulness or 
happiness with his or her choices.
• Of course, in our daily life, we don’t measure such a thing. But, in model, it can be a quite useful 
instrument to replicate the underlying incentive structure of each individuals.
2. Utility
Economists assume the feature of utility
1.The more of some good one consumes, the more utility 
one obtains.
2. As a person consumes more of a good, the additional (or 
marginal) utility from each additional unit of the good 
declines.
2. Utility
• It is a general pattern that consumption of the first few units of good tends to bring a higher level of 
utility than consumption of later units.
• Suppose that you are in thirsty. You can compare the degree to which the first few drops of water relieve 
the thirst and the extent to which the drinking water later resolves the thirst.
• Economists refer to this pattern as the law of diminishing marginal utility.
• It means that, the utility of a person receives from consuming the first unit of a good is typically more 
than the utility received from consuming the fifth or the tenth unit of that same good.
2. Utility
• The law of diminishing marginal utility explains why people and societies rarely make all-or-nothing 
choices. 
• Most of people would not say, “My favorite food is potato, so I will eat nothing but only potatoes from 
now on.”
• Even if you get a very high level of utility from your favorite food, if you ate it exclusively, the marginal 
utility from those last few servings would not be very high.

**Keywords**

Producer’s optimization problem
◦ Business sector or firms combines inputs of labor, capital, land, and raw or 
finished component materials to produce outputs.
◦ This activity of production includes not only manufacturing but also any 
process or service that creates value, including transportation, distribution, 
wholesale and retail sales.
◦ The objective of business : profit
Producer’s optimization problem
◦ Profit = Revenue – cost
◦ Revenue = Price × Quantity
◦ Cost = the amount that the firm pays to make and sell their products is called total cost. 
◦ The cost structure of firms can be broken down into some 
common underlying patterns. In the short run, we can classify the 
costs into fixed costs and variable costs.
◦ Fixed costs are the costs that cannot be changed in the short run.
◦ Variable costs are the costs that can be changed.
The structure of production cost
◦ Fixed costs are expenditures that do not change regardless of the level of 
production, at least not in the short term.
◦ For example, the cost of building factory or buying heavy equipment, research and 
development costs, advertising expenses. 
◦ The level of fixed costs varies according to the feature of the products or 
industry. 
◦ For instance, manufacturing mobile phone or computer chips requires an 
expensive factory. But, a food-truck or a painting artist can get by with 
relatively less fixed costs.
The structure of production cost
◦ Variable costs are incurred in the act of producing.
◦ For example, wages and cost to buy intermediate goods are variable costs.
◦ The more you produce, the greater the variable cost.
◦ Total cost = fixed cost + variable cost.
The nature of production
◦ Two assumptions:
1. Positivity (with respect to input)
2. Law of diminishing marginal production
◦ Marginal product of any input : the additional quantity of output obtained 
from one additional unit of that input.
Example : Pepe’s chicken house
◦ Assume that the fixed costs of operating the chicken house, including the space and 
equipment, are 100.
◦ The variable costs are the costs of hiring worker, which in our example is 50 per deliver. 
◦ Variable cost :  price of input  x  quantity of input.
◦ When one unit of the input (worker) is added, the cost would be increased as much as the 
price of the input (50 for the wage).

Price, however, is not the only thing that influences demand and supply.
What if overall consumer’s income has changed? 
Sometime preferences can be suddenly changed.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected?

5. Shift of demand curve
Does the higher income always bring greater demand?
A product whose demand rises when income rises is called a normal good.
but, there is a few exceptions to this pattern do exist. 
A product whose demand falls when income rises is called an inferior good. 
5. Shift of demand curve
And, for some goods such as luxury cars, fine cuisines, or jewelry, the effect of 
a rise in income can be especially pronounced.
We called those luxury goods.
A luxury good is a good for which demand increases more than proportionally 
as income rises, 
5. Shift of demand curve
Of course, income is not the only factor that causes a shift in demand.
We can think about some of other factors that shift demand curves.
One of those is changing tastes or preferences.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
It might cause a severe avoiding to eat chickens.
5. Shift of demand curve
Demographic changes can also be a important factor.
Actually, the demographic changes is combined with the changes in preference.
Since the consumption preference of youth and old person is quite different, 
changes in the demographic structure directly affects the overall preference of 
the society.
5. Shift of demand curve
Another example is the housing demand.
Since the demand for owning houses is usually peaked in the middle age about 
40s, the overall housing demand can also be peaked, when the number of 
middle-aged in the country is the highest level.
Some economists have tried to predict the future housing prices by using 
predictable demographic changes.
Mankiw, N. G., & Weil, D. N. (1989). The baby boom, the baby bust, and the 
housing market. Regional science and urban economics, 19(2), 235-258.
5. Shift of demand curve
It is also true that expectations about the future price (or expectations about 
tastes and preferences, income, and so on) can affect demand.
For example, if people hear that a hurricane is coming, they may rush to the 
store to buy flashlight batteries and bottled water. 
These changes can push the demand curve to the right.
5. Shift of demand curve
One interest thing is that some goods can be seriously affected by the 
expectation.
For example, we can think about housing market.
Demand for housing is not only determined  by preferences, but also by the 
expectations for capital gain.
This feature of housing markets sometimes causes speculations in housing 
markets.
6. Shift of supply curve
How about the supply curves? 
One of most important factor affecting the supply curve might be the 
production cost.
If a firm faces lower costs of production, a firm’s profits go up. This can be 
shown by the supply curve shifting to the right.
if a firm faces higher costs of production, then it will earn lower profits at any 
given selling price for its products. In this case, the supply curve shifts to the 
left.
6. Shift of supply curve

6. Shift of supply curve
Several other things affect the cost of production, too. 
We can think about new technologies for production, and some government 
policies.
6. Shift of supply curve
When producers develops or discovers a technology that allows the firm to 
produce at a lower cost, the supply curve will shift to the right, as well. 
Think about the cost of raising a chicken in chicken farm and the poultry 
factory system.
6. Shift of supply curve
Government policies also can affect the cost of production and the supply 
curve through taxes, regulations, and subsidies.
A subsidy occurs when the government pays a firm directly or reduces the 
firm’s taxes if the firm carries out certain actions. 
From the firm’s perspective, taxes or regulations are an additional cost of 
production that shifts supply to the left, leading the firm to produce a lower 
quantity at every given price. 
So, government subsidies reduce the cost of production and increase supply at 
every given price, shifting supply to the right.

◦ Business sector or firms combines inputs of labor, capital, land, and raw or

costs into fixed costs and variable costs.

◦ Variable costs are the costs that can be changed.
The structure of production cost
◦ Fixed costs are expenditures that do not change regardless of the level of 
production, at least not in the short term.

industry.

relatively less fixed costs.

Price, however, is not the only thing that influences demand and supply.
What if overall consumer’s income has changed? 
Sometime preferences can be suddenly changed.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected?

5. Shift of demand curve
Does the higher income always bring greater demand?
A product whose demand rises when income rises is called a normal good.
but, there is a few exceptions to this pattern do exist. 
A product whose demand falls when income rises is called an inferior good. 
5. Shift of demand curve
And, for some goods such as luxury cars, fine cuisines, or jewelry, the effect of 
a rise in income can be especially pronounced.
We called those luxury goods.
A luxury good is a good for which demand increases more than proportionally 
as income rises, 
5. Shift of demand curve
Of course, income is not the only factor that causes a shift in demand.
We can think about some of other factors that shift demand curves.
One of those is changing tastes or preferences.
For example, if avian influenza has occurred, how is demand for chicken 
affected? 
It might cause a severe avoiding to eat chickens.
5. Shift of demand curve
Demographic changes can also be a important factor.
Actually, the demographic changes is combined with the changes in preference.
Since the consumption preference of youth and old person is quite different, 
changes in the demographic structure directly affects the overall preference of 
the society.
5. Shift of demand curve
Another example is the housing demand.
Since the demand for owning houses is usually peaked in the middle age about 
40s, the overall housing demand can also be peaked, when the number of 
middle-aged in the country is the highest level.
Some economists have tried to predict the future housing prices by using 
predictable demographic changes.
Mankiw, N. G., & Weil, D. N. (1989). The baby boom, the baby bust, and the 
housing market. Regional science and urban economics, 19(2), 235-258.
5. Shift of demand curve
It is also true that expectations about the future price (or expectations about 
tastes and preferences, income, and so on) can affect demand.
For example, if people hear that a hurricane is coming, they may rush to the 
store to buy flashlight batteries and bottled water. 
These changes can push the demand curve to the right.
5. Shift of demand curve
One interest thing is that some goods can be seriously affected by the 
expectation.
For example, we can think about housing market.
Demand for housing is not only determined  by preferences, but also by the 
expectations for capital gain.
This feature of housing markets sometimes causes speculations in housing 
markets.
6. Shift of supply curve
How about the supply curves? 
One of most important factor affecting the supply curve might be the 
production cost.
If a firm faces lower costs of production, a firm’s profits go up. This can be 
shown by the supply curve shifting to the right.
if a firm faces higher costs of production, then it will earn lower profits at any 
given selling price for its products. In this case, the supply curve shifts to the 
left.
6. Shift of supply curve

6. Shift of supply curve
Several other things affect the cost of production, too. 
We can think about new technologies for production, and some government 
policies.
6. Shift of supply curve
When producers develops or discovers a technology that allows the firm to 
produce at a lower cost, the supply curve will shift to the right, as well. 
Think about the cost of raising a chicken in chicken farm and the poultry 
factory system.
6. Shift of supply curve
Government policies also can affect the cost of production and the supply 
curve through taxes, regulations, and subsidies.
A subsidy occurs when the government pays a firm directly or reduces the 
firm’s taxes if the firm carries out certain actions. 
From the firm’s perspective, taxes or regulations are an additional cost of 
production that shifts supply to the left, leading the firm to produce a lower 
quantity at every given price. 
So, government subsidies reduce the cost of production and increase supply at 
every given price, shifting supply to the right.

2. Utility
• It is a general pattern that consumption of the first few units of good tends to bring a higher level of 
utility than consumption of later units.
• Suppose that you are in thirsty. You can compare the degree to which the first few drops of water relieve 
the thirst and the extent to which the drinking water later resolves the thirst.
• Economists refer to this pattern as the law of diminishing marginal utility.
• It means that, the utility of a person receives from consuming the first unit of a good is typically more 
than the utility received from consuming the fifth or the tenth unit of that same good.

choices.

now on.”

utility from those last few servings would not be very high.
